author: Diario de Sevilla
title: Fernando serÃ¡ despedido ante el Athletic tras rescindir su contrato
text: Fernando Reges no volverÃ¡ a jugar en el Sevilla. Es mÃ¡s, algunas informaciones apuntan a que ya ha habido acuerdo para la rescisiÃ³n de su contrato, que vencÃ­a en junio, extremo confirmado por este diario. La idea del club es que sea despedido con honores y que se le realice un homenaje en el primer partido del aÃ±o, el Sevilla-Athletic que se disputarÃ¡ el jueves 4 de enero en el RamÃ³n SÃ¡nchez-PizjuÃ¡n a las 19:15. SegÃºn la cuenta en la red social X de El Chiringuito, ya se ha producido el esperado acuerdo entre las partes. El club tenÃ­a buena disposiciÃ³n a liberar a Fernando de su compromiso contractual, en la necesidad tambiÃ©n de hacer hueco en la primera plantilla al delantero de 23 aÃ±os Isaac Romero, que necesita ficha en LaLiga para poder ascender, dado que ya no es sub 23. ðŸš¨ Â¡FERNANDO NO seguirÃ¡ en el SEVILLA!ðŸ¤ Ha llegado a un acuerdo con el club esta tarde para la rescisiÃ³n del contrato.ðŸ‘‰ El club quiere homenajearlo contra el Athletic.ðŸ“ InformaciÃ³n deâ€” El Chiringuito TV (@elchiringuitotv) [@GonzaloTortosa] [pic.twitter.com/KAepwK7Tkb] [December 28, 2023] AsÃ­ lo reconociÃ³ recientemente VÃ­ctor Orta: "Con Fernando estamos hablando tras una exposiciÃ³n personal que nos ha hecho y pronto habrÃ¡ novedades". El futbolista tambiÃ©n ha puesto mucho de su parte, al renunciar a lo que le corresponde de emolumentos hasta el final de temporada desde enero. En el Sevilla entienden que los servicios del formidable mediocampista brasileÃ±o han sido sobrados, al haberse destacado como uno de los mejores medios de cierre de la historia reciente y pilar del equipo en los Ã©xitos durante sus cuatro temporadas -sin contar la actual-, desde su llegada en el verano de 2019: dos copas de la Europa League y cuatro clasificaciones consecutivas a la Champions. A sus 36 aÃ±os, Fernando ya habÃ­a declarado pÃºblicamente que estaba ante su Ãºltima temporada en el Sevilla, donde ya no puede rendir a nivel de un club de su exigencia. Y esto se ha unido a su deseo de repatriarse ya y a la necesidad del club de liberar fichas.

author: Evan Craig
title: Rams were smart not to re-sign Von Miller back in the 2022 offseason
text: At the 2021 NFL trade deadline, the [Los Angeles Rams](https://www.turfshowtimes.com/) traded for future Hall of Famer Von Miller in a blockbuster move that eventually pushed LA over the top. Miller had four sacks during the playoffs, including two in the [Super Bowl](https://www.sbnation.com/super-bowl) that enabled the Rams to put away the pesky [Cincinnati Bengals](https://www.cincyjungle.com/). Los Angeles had a chance to re-sign him the following offseason but was way outbid by the [Buffalo Bills](https://www.buffalorumblings.com/) who signed him to a six-year, $120 million deal. Vonâ€™s debut with the Bills came during the 2022 season opener against his old team at SoFi Stadium. Initially, letting Miller walk appeared to be a very bad look for general manager Les Snead. Von Miller in his Bills debut:â€” PFF (@PFF) 25 pass-rushing snaps 4 pressures 2 sacks 89.8 PFF Grade (1st among Bills defenders) ( [@NFL]) [pic.twitter.com/imJMGtLaaB] [September 9, 2022] Instead, Snead and the Rams have to be feeling pretty damn smart as Buffalo is probably experiencing some buyerâ€™s remorse at the moment. Miller has failed to become much of an impact player with his current team. After recording eight sacks and 12 QB hits in â€˜22, the All-Pro defender has failed to register a sack and only has three total tackles [in 11 games this season](https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/M/MillVo00.htm). He has also played just 32 percent of the snaps on defense. In all fairness, Von is working his way back from a torn ACL he suffered last December and was activated off IR on October 7. Still, itâ€™s not a great look when a backup defensive tackle has more sacks than one of the NFLâ€™s all-time greatest sack masters. Sacks this season:â€” Dan Fetes (@danfetes) Poona Ford: 1 Von Miller: 0 [#BillsMafia] [@BuffaloPlus] [December 24, 2023] Back in January, [TSTâ€™s own Kenneth Arthur](https://www.turfshowtimes.com/2023/1/26/23573297/von-miller-rams-contract-bills-injury) wrote about how hesitating in re-signing Miller was warranted as the veteran wouldâ€™ve been just another â€˜22 injury casualty. Given the state of the Rams last year, the roster couldnâ€™t afford to have an aging player on a premium contract missing extensive time. Fair or not, Miller is clearly not a Defensive Player of the Year candidate anymore. With [troubling assault allegations](https://twitter.com/DomTibbettsTV/status/1740464796947173558?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet) that have yet to be resolved, LA was very fortunate Von chased the guaranteed money Buffalo offered. I will make it very clear that the goal of this post is not to throw Miller under the bus. Itâ€™s simply worth pointing out that sometimes the best contracts are the ones not taken. LA is in a better spot with younger contributors on defense who will be part of the foundation for years to come. Miller was never going to be more than a rental in Hollywood as teams are always willing to take a chance on a player with his resume, regardless of age. The Bills took that gamble and lost. But that is not an excuse for certain members of the fanbase to rub the bad contract in the Billsâ€™ noses. Von Miller commands respect for his contributions to the Rams during his brief stay as LA would not have won a ring without him. Rams fans who are talking shit on Von Miller and talking about how we dodged a bullet is a bad look. Bro came in and helped us get a Ring. Be thankful he got a bag from the Bills and just focus on our teams future no need to shit talk a dude that didnâ€™t do anything to hurt usâ€” Matt (@matt08buzz) [December 27, 2023]

author: VNExplorer
title: UK's oldest WW2 veteran honoured by Spitfire flypast
text: Donald Rose celebrated his 109th birthday in December Dozens of people watched a Spitfire fly over a Derbyshire care home in honour of the UKâ€™s oldest surviving World War Two veteran. Donald Rose, aged 109, served in the war on the front line with the 7th Armoured Division. The iconic aircraft passed over his care home in Ilkeston on Monday afternoon. The plane was taking part in the Royal Airforceâ€™s Battle of Britain memorial flight. The flypast happened after Naomi Allsop, activity coordinator at Canal View Care Home, wrote to the RAF asking for them to honour Mr Rose. She said she was initially told it would not be possible until she received the go-ahead for the tribute two weeks ago. Ms Allsop said: â€œSince 2021 Iâ€™ve been ticking off things for Donald for his bucket list but this is like the cherry on the cake for him. â€œIâ€™ve been writing to the RAF every year to see if they could do a flyover for his birthday but Iâ€™ve never had a reply back. â€œTo have this organised at a care home is just incredible, and Donald loves Spitfires and knows everything about them. â€œAfter three years of trying to make it happen; itâ€™s just amazing.â€ Born in 1914, Mr Rose joined the Queenâ€™s Royal Regiment aged 25 and served in North Africa and Europe before training as a sniper. The flypast, which happened at about 13:45 BST, took place amid a range of events to commemorate World War Two and honour the armed forces. Ms Allsop said the local community came together to celebrate the special occasion at the care home. In 2022, Mr Rose received more than 150 messages from well-wishers after a public appeal for people to send him birthday cards. He also received a visit from the Mayor of Erewash on the most recent Armistice Day. Naomi Allsop helped organise the flypast for Mr Rose Follow BBC East Midlands on Facebook, on Twitter, or on Instagram. Send your story ideas to eastmidsnews@bbc.co.uk.

author: yahoo
title: 'Shield Grampy' sentenced to prison by judge handling Trump's Jan. 6 case
text:
'Shield Grampy' sentenced to prison by judge handling Trump's Jan. 6 case Ryan J. Reilly June 28, 2024 at 12:59 AM
WASHINGTON â€” The federal judge overseeing presumptive Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's Jan. 6 criminal case on Thursday sentenced a Capitol rioter who assaulted police officers to more than 4.5 years in prison.
Anthony Mastanduno â€” known to online sleuths as " Shield Grampy " â€” pleaded guilty to nine criminal offenses in March, which was when Trump was originally supposed to be on trial in his own Capitol attack case under the trial schedule laid out by Judge Tanya Chutkan back in August. (Trump's case was paused as the Supreme Court considers his immunity claim.)
Mastanduno's arrest came in August 2023, a few weeks after Trump was arrested in the Jan. 6 case against him brought by special counsel Jack Smith.
But Mastanduno's case has not been subjected to the same delays as the Trump case. Chutkan ordered Mastanduno into custody after he pleaded guilty in March. Trump, by comparison, is appearing Thursday night at a debate with President Joe Biden.
dc riot rioter capitol january 6, 2021 Anthony Mastanduno (U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia) Federal prosecutors had argued for six years behind bars for Mastanduno, saying he "participated in some of the worst violence inflicted upon law enforcement officers at the Lower West Terrace Tunnel during the assault on the United States Capitol."
One officer Mastanduno assaulted called Jan. 6 "horrific" and "life-changing," saying the memories left him having trouble sleeping and difficulty trusting others. He considers Jan. 6 to be â€œforever [his] [d]arkest day," prosecutors wrote.
A defense memo cited Mastanduno's work as a volunteer firefighter and his time in the Marine Corps, and it includes a lengthy redacted section about the 61-year-old's physical and mental health.
In the nearly 3.5 years since the Capitol attack, federal prosecutors have charged more than 1,400 people and secured convictions against over 1,000 defendants. More than 540 of those defendants have been sentenced to periods of incarceration that range from a few days behind bars to 22 years in federal prison for a Proud Boys leader convicted of seditious conspiracy .

author: University of Utah
title: Cosmic ray detectors, built by Utah refugee teens, installed on Refugee Services Center
text: The detectors, which measure echoes of cosmic particles bombarding Earthâ€™s atmosphere, were built by nearly 60 participants in a program called â€œInvestigating the Development of STEM-Positive Identities of Refugee Teens in a Physics Out of School Time Experienceâ€ ( InSPIRE ), which brings science researchâ€”in this case particle physicsâ€”to teenagers and contributes to a worldwide effort to measure cosmic ray activity on Earth. â€œRefugee youth often encounter many challenges related to STEM, including restricted exposure to STEM education, language barriers, cultural adjustments and a history of interrupted schooling, resulting in a low rate of high school completion and college matriculation among refugee students,â€ said Tino Nyawelo, principal investigator of InSPIRE, professor of physics and astronomy at the U and a leader in Utahâ€™s refugee community. Nyaweloâ€™s wifeâ€™s family and many of his friends and classmates were relocated to Salt Lake City after fleeing violence at the outbreak of the Sudanese civil war. â€œThe project conducts research to better understand these challenges and how to best broaden access to and engagement in STEM for refugee youth and other historically disenfranchised populations.â€ InSPIRE brings together the University of Utah, Utah State University, Utah Department of Workforce Services Refugee Services Office, as well as the Dutch National Institute for Subatomic Physics (Nikhef), to involve teens in real science. Data from the studentsâ€™ cosmic ray detectors help us understand the origins of the universe. Funded by a $1.1 million Advancing Informal STEM Learning grant from the U.S. National Science Foundation, InSPIRE explores how refugee teenagers identify with STEM subjects while participating in research. Fifty-seven refugee teens spent one to two days a week for nearly three years building the detectors while learning particle physics and computer programming. The students designed their own research projects, posing questions such as whether the moonâ€™s effects on cosmic rays hitting Earth. While some participants worked on the detectors, others focused on crafting films of their fellow studentsâ€™ research journeys. These students are working on a documentary, in partnership with the ArtsBridge America program at the Uâ€™s College of Fine Arts. â€œWe want students with refugee backgrounds to know that they are valued in physics and in STEM disciplines more broadly,â€ said Sarah Braden, InSPIRE co-principal investigator and associate professor of cultural studies at USUâ€™s College of Education and Human Services. â€œThese students learned physics, computing and filming techniques, and they brought their ingenuity, curiosity, resilience and playfulness. Knowingly or not, the students are helping to transform the discipline in which they participate, opening new pathways for themselves and for other students to see themselves as valued contributors to STEM disciplines.â€ The groupâ€™s peer-reviewed publications describe the ways in which the program supported students in engaging with their multilingualism, and the importance of encouraging spontaneous play in informal STEM environments. As one participant shared, â€œI didnâ€™t know I was interested in STEM. But when we did the building and the soldering and the calibrating, I learned I have a passion for science. And Iâ€™m more confident now in science-related topics, especially when the activities are more than sitting and learning.â€ InSPIRE is embedded within Refugees Exploring the Foundations of Undergraduate Education In Science ( REFUGES ), an afterschool program that helps refugee youth thrive in STEM. Nywelo and other members of the refugee community founded REFUGES in 2009 because they were alarmed at the high rates of school dropouts. They realized that many refugee youth come to Utah with little English and intermittent formal schooling. The Utah school system places them in a grade based on their age, leaving many feeling overwhelmed and left behind. The Uâ€™s Center for Science and Mathematics Education ( CSME ) has housed the program since 2012, where it has expanded to include non-refugee students who are underrepresented in STEM fields. Since then, REFUGES has worked closely with Utahâ€™s Department of Workforce Services Refugee Services Office, which serves as a critical link to the refugee community by coordinating comprehensive services to refugees resettled in our state. â€œFor the past 12 years, the Refugee Services Office has collaborated with the REFUGES program to identify refugee students and their families who need academic assistance and support. Participation in REFUGES keeps these students engaged in their community while also promoting their access to educational opportunities,â€ said Mario Kljajo, director of the Utah RSO. â€œItâ€™s amazingâ€”what started as a small project funded by a Refugee Services Office grant has grown into a multi-million-dollar endeavor backed by national organizations.â€ The detector technology is adapted from HiSPARC (High School Project on Astrophysics Research with Cosmics), a collaboration that started in the Netherlands aimed at improving high schoolersâ€™ interest in physics. There are now more than 140 student-built detectors on buildings in the Netherlands, Namibia and the United Kingdom that upload data 24/7 to publicly available databases. Nikhef coordinated the project from 2003-2023 and created the initial worldwide network of cosmic ray detection data. Starting in 2024, the Uâ€™s Center for High Performance Computing ( CHPC ) will take over hosting and maintaining the data on extensive cosmic air showers and digital HiSPARC infrastructure, led by Nyawelo. â€œThis important work would not have been possible without the collaboration between the University of Utah and Utah State University,â€ said Jordan Gerton, InSPIRE co-principal investigator and professor of physics and astronomy at the U. â€œSarahâ€™s team at USU led pioneering research that sheds light on how students from historically marginalized groups develop a sense of belonging in STEM; equally important, their expertise enabled the students to experience an environment supportive of their individual cultures, languages, and varied experiences. This project leveraged the strengths of both institutions, and has built the foundation for continued work with K-12 students and, critically, teachers.â€ Students all over Utah will soon be able to participateâ€”the U.S. NSF recently awarded the InSPIRE team $1 million to fund Research Experiences for Undergraduates ( REU ) and Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) here in Utah. RET seeks to integrate high school education with professional scientific research in experimental cosmic-ray physics by training local teachers. â€œWith data from the detectors, youâ€™ll be able to figure out where the showers came from, or do atmospheric studies like how pressure impacts the rates of cosmic rays,â€ said John Matthews, InSPIRE co-principal investigator who runs the Uâ€™s Telescope Array cosmic array project in Delta, Utah. â€œHopefully, these students learn something about equipment and the scientific process and have fun at the same time. InSPIRE is funded by U.S. National Science Foundation Advancing Informal STEM Learning award #: 2005973, and U.S. NSFâ€™s Research Experiences for Undergraduates and Research Experiences for Teachers award #: 2349237. For b-roll and photos of both the installation event and the InSPIRE program, email [[email protected]](/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#dbb7b2a8baf5abb4afafbea99baeafbab3f5bebfae). MEDIA CONTACT [Register for reporter access to contact details](/users/register)
